Award.AwardTitle: Bridge to Research in Environmental and Applied Metagenomics: An inquiry-based module to build core STEM competencies and improve retention among underrepresented students

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
A major goal of current efforts to improve life science education is to provide opportunities for students to engage in original research. The Bridge to Research in Environmental and Applied Genomics (BREAM) project is a scaffolded inquiry-based teaching and learning module that seeks to develop, implement, and assess a transformative STEM experience for first-year students through inquiry-based, relevant science experiences. The long-term goal is to develop a model for undergraduate research that provides students with early research experience in a relevant and truly meaningful social context at an urban college. In the context of a pressing local environmental issue, the restoration of Jamaica Bay in New York City, students will learn to use cutting-edge scientific tools, such as applied environmental metagenomics, to investigate ecosystem function and the restoration of urban estuaries. The project will be implemented at York College/CUNY, drawing participants from a diverse student population. This effort is ideally timed to take advantage of the newly energized relationship between CUNY, the City of New York, and other partners with the goal of understanding and restoring Jamaica Bay.

This project will bring together several research-informed practices (such as problem-based learning, authentic research experiences, and scaffolded instruction) that have been shown to be effective in STEM education with more novel elements intended to improve student motivation, confidence and expertise. Scaffolded activities will introduce students to concepts like hypothesis development, scientific literature review, and experimental design, with an overwhelming emphasis on active participation. The project will assess whether explicit scaffolding in an inquiry-based program improves learning and retention in STEM majors. Project outcomes will be rigorously assessed by external evaluators based on measured changes in scientific literacy, critical thinking skills, and communication. The BREAM module will be ultimately disseminated to educators at regional two- and four-year institutions through seminars and training workshops.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The continued advancement of our national interests in science and technology requires a workforce and citizenry literate in STEM (science, technology, engineering and mathematics) concepts and skills. To improve retention and academic success in STEM, educators must offer students earlier opportunities to engage in real science, as it is actually practiced: cross-disciplinary, cutting-edge, and collaborative. This project designed, implemented and assessed an educational module called the Bridge to Research in Environmental and Applied Metagenomics, or BREAM. BREAM is a research-based module for first-year students, and was implemented with at an urban college in the context of a pressing local environmental issue: the restoration of Jamaica Bay in New York City. Over 158 college students participated in the BREAM project, and learned to use cutting-edge scientific tools, such as applied environmental metagenomics, to investigate ecosystem function and the restoration of urban estuaries. They were also trained in core competencies in the sciences including experimental design, science communication and specific quantitative skills. Students interacted with local agencies and environmental organizations to experience, first-hand, how scientific data can be used in policy and management contexts.

 

The BREAM project used several research-informed practices shown to be effective in STEM education (problem-based learning, authentic research experiences, scaffolded instruction) and combined them with more novel elements intended to improve student motivation, confidence and expertise (focus on a local environmental issue, one-on-one peer mentoring, focus on first-year students, training in modern analytic tools such as bioinformatics, and an emphasis on science communication). The project was assessed by measuring changes in scientific literacy, engagement and critical thinking skills, communication, the proportion of students that go on to major in STEM disciplines, and interest in scientific careers. The results of assessment indicate that this model was very successful in helping students develop an idea of how to operate as a scientist and to see themselves through that lens. Participants, who had little to no previous experience in metagenomic data collection and analysis, learned how to conduct fieldwork, labwork, and computational analysis, and self-reported an improvement of 114% in 18 skills and concepts taught in the module. In the process, students also contributed valuable knowledge about a local environmental problem and learned how to communicate their scientific results in oral and written presentations. Likewise, senior students who acted as peer mentors gained leadership experience, and independent evaluations indicate that the mentoring experience helped solidify their own STEM learning and that they would seek out similar experiences in the future. Some improvements in retention and pursuit of a STEM major were observed; additional longitudinal studies are needed to determine the significance of these gains.
